Row.Text: The history of Spain's missions in the American South and Southwest reveals much about Spain's strategy, contributions, and failures in these regions. The expeditions of Francisco Vázquez de Coronado (1540 42) and Juan de Oñate (1598) convinced Spanish authorities that no wealthy Indian empires like that of the Aztecs were to be found north of Mexico. Consequently the Spanish came to view the northern frontier of their empire as a defensive barrier and as a place where pagan souls might be saved. In what are now the states of Florida, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California, missions were founded to propagate the doctrines of the Roman Catholic church. To protect these missions as well as the mines and ranches of Mexico from attack from the north, the Spanish established presidios fortified garrisons of troops. Franciscan priests founded a series of missions in Florida after 1573, mainly along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts. The first missions in New Mexico were established by friars accompanying Oñate's expedition of 1598; during the next 100 years Franciscan priests founded more than 40 additional missions, most of them along the Rio Grande. Especially influential was Father Alonso de Benavides, who directed the founding of 10 missions between 1625 and 1629 and thereafter promoted them ably in Spain. By 1680 missions had been established among most of the New Mexican Indians.

When constructed, receive a free Missionary that follows your [ICON_RELIGION] Religion. Every time a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born in this City, receive [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_GOLD] Gold. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Boosts Pressure of [ICON_RELIGION] Religious Majority emanating from this city by 15%. Does not require Walls in order to be built.

Unique Spanish replacement for the Castle. It is cheaper than the Castle, has no maintenance, and does not require Walls in order to be built. Grants Faith and Gold when Citizens are born in the City, as well as a free Missionary when constructed. The free Missionary will follow your founded Religion or, if you have not founded a religion, it will follow your majority Religion. Boosts the city's religious pressure by 10% and resistance to foreign conversion by 20%, thus making the city more effective at converting nearby cities and harder for others to convert! Build these unique Castles to quickly boost a City's Defense, bypass the need for Walls, and to bolster your Religion.

The Jelling stones are massive carved runestones from the 10th century, found at the town of Jelling in Denmark. The older of the two Jelling stones was raised by King Gorm the Old in memory of his wife Thyra. The larger of the two stones was raised by King Gorm's son, Harald Bluetooth in memory of his parents, celebrating his conquest of Denmark and Norway, and his conversion of the Danes to Christianity. The runic inscriptions on these stones are considered the most well known in Denmark.

+15% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person rate, +2 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism (once Drama is researched) and an instant boost of 25 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food from Ocean Tiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Each source of [ICON_RES_FISH] Fish worked by this City produces +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.

Unique Danish replacement for the Lighthouse. In addition to the Lighthouse's bonuses, Jelling Stones produces +2 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism (once Drama is researched), +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and increases the Great Person rate for the city where it is built by 15%. Grants 25 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture when completed. Unlike the Lighthouse, the City does not have to be built on the coast.

Seowon were the most common educational institution of Korea during the mid- to late Joseon Dynasty. They were private institutions, and combined the functions of a Confucian shrine and a preparatory school. In educational terms, the seowon were primarily occupied with preparing students for the national civil service examinations. In most cases, seowon served only pupils of the aristocratic yangban class.

+20% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person rate in this City. +1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science from Jungle and Forest tiles worked by this City. Gain 50% of the [ICON_RESEARCH] Science output of the City as an instant boost to your current Research when a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born in this City. Reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Illiteracy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Allows Archaeologists to be built in this city. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a Library.

Unique Korean replacement for the University. Generates more Science than the University, and also generates Faith. The increased Great Person rate will help you produce Great People more quickly, thus helping you to maximize Korea's Unique Ability.

A yurt, called a 'Ger' by Mongolians, is a portable, bent dwelling structure traditionally used by nomads in the steppes of Central Asia as their home. The structure comprises a crown or compression wheel, usually steam bent, supported by roof ribs which are bent down at the end where they meet the lattice wall (again, steam bent). The top of the wall is prevented from spreading by means of a tension band which opposes the force of the roof ribs. The structure is usually covered by layers of fabric and sheep's wool felt for insulation and weatherproofing. The traditional decoration within a yurt is primarily pattern based. These patterns are generally not according to taste, but are derived from sacred ornaments with certain symbolism. Symbols representing strength are among the most common, including the khas (swastika) and four powerful beasts (lion, tiger, garuda and dragon), as well as stylized representations of the five elements (fire, water, earth, metal, and wood), considered to be the fundamental, unchanging elements of the cosmos. Such patterns are commonly used in the home with the belief that they will bring strength and offer protection.

Each source of [ICON_RES_COW] Cows [ICON_RES_SHEEP] Sheep and [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horses worked by this City produce +3 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Allows [ICON_FOOD] Food to be moved from this city along trade routes inside your civilization.

Unique Mongolian replacement for the Granary. Unlike the Granary, the Ger provides Food from livestock instead of crops. It also provides a small amount of Faith, and has no maintenance. Build Gers in your cities to maximize their growth, and to get an early Pantheon.
